About this guide

This guide was forked from @mdo's code guide. In order to compile it you will need to have Jekyll installed as well as Python >= 2.7.5.

Why have a code style guide?

Websites change, additions are made and designs/user experience iterate. In general, a structured approach to code:

  • is easier for others to understand
  • makes code immediately parseable
  • is more future friendly
  • better for long term maintainability
  • should be able to confidently delete a component with impunity (it's ok to not make things reusable!)

Establishing a standard of code quality makes the codebase familiar, transparent, readable and more maintainable. Coding conventions mean your brain doesn't have to make a mental leap every time you look at a piece of code— be it HTML, CSS or JavaScript

Consistency instills confidence; it makes you a more productive developer and we become more confident in the products we are producing. The focus should be on developing a system rather than a set of individual pages and one-offs disconnected from the whole.

The point of having style guidelines is to have a common vocabulary of coding so people can concentrate on what you're saying rather than on how you're saying it. Every line of code should appear to be written by a single person, no matter the number of contributors.

HTML

General practices

  • Use soft tabs with two spaces— they're the only way to guarantee code renders the same in any environment
  • Nested elements should be indented once (two spaces)
  • Always use double quotes, never single quotes, on attributes
  • Declare a character set (UTF-8)
  • Use an HTML5 doctype: enforce standards mode and more consistent rendering in every browser possible with this simple doctype
  • TODO: add a doctype on mobile web (!!!)
  • Enable the best standards support possible for IE with the X-UA-Compatible meta tag
  • Avoid inline styles
  • Don't include a trailing slash in self-closing elements— the HTML5 spec says they're optional.
  • Use the right tag for the applicable context. For example, use a h3 instead of something ridiculous like <span class="heading">.
  • Be aware of what semantics in HTML(5) are all about but don't get stressed out over it
  • See also: Editor configuration
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en-ca">
  <head>
    <title>Page title</title>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=Edge">
  </head>
  <body>
    <img src="images/company-logo.png" alt="Company">
    <script>
    var x = 1;
    </script>
    <h1>Hello, world!</h1>
  </body>
</html>

Microdata

  • used to nest metadata within existing content on web pages
  • microdata is machine-readable: search engines, web crawlers, and browsers can extract and process microdata from a web page and use it to provide a richer browsing experience for users
  • structured microdata allows search engines to understand the content of the web page and provide more relavant search results to users
  • we should use microdata as much as possible to enrich the user experience by helping search engines discover our content
  • use schema.org as a starting point for adding microdata to your HTML
  • itemscope: the data within is "about" a particular thing
  • itemtype: specifies the type of item within; always immediately follows itemscope
  • itemprop: identifies properties of an item
<!-- without micordata -->
<article>
  <h1>World risks new financial crisis amid ‘poisonous’ mix: study</h1>
  <p class="author">by John Smith</p>
  <time class="published">Published Sept. 26, 2014, 10:02am EDT</time>
</article>

<!-- with micordata -->
<article itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/NewsArticle">
  <h1 itemprop="headline">World risks new financial crisis amid ‘poisonous’ mix: study</h1>
  <p class="author" itemprop="author">by John Smith</p>
  <time class="published" itemprop="datePublished">Published Sept. 26, 2014, 10:02am EDT</time>
</article>

Accessibility

  • enabling as many people as possible to use web sites, even when those people's abilities are limited in some way
  • MDN documentation on accessibility
  • use best-practices you already know: title="attributes" and <img alt="Alternate text">
  • ARIA defines ways to make web content/applications more accessible: it is "a framework for adding attributes to identify features for user interaction, how they relate to each other, and their current state"
  • use ARIA landmarks
    • …landmark roles ("landmarks") programmatically identify sections of a page. They help assistive technology users orient themselves to a page and help them navigate easily to various sections of a page. www.w3.org/WAI
  • the "role" attribute should not be placed on another element that already has semantic meaning. It should only be placed on <div> and <span> elements.
  • TODO: aria-label and aria-labelledby
<!-- without ARIA roles -->
<div class="nav">
  <ul>
    <li>Home</li>
    <li>Products</li>
    <li>Support</li>
  </ul>
</div>
<div class="main-content">
  <p>Hello, I am the main content of the page</p>
</div>
<div class="secondary-content">
  <p>I am additional, complimentary content but not the main content of this page</p>
</div>

<!-- with ARIA roles -->
<div class="nav" role="navigation">
  <!-- alternatively, a <nav> tag could be used above with no role attribute -->
  <ul>
    <li>Home</li>
    <li>Products</li>
    <li>Support</li>
  </ul>
</div>
<div class="main-content" role="main">
  <p>Hello, I am the main content of the page</p>
</div>
<div class="secondary-content" role="secondary">
  <p>I am additional, complimentary content but not the main content of this page</p>
</div>

CSS and JavaScript includes

Per HTML5 spec, typically there is no need to specify a type when including CSS and JavaScript files as text/css and text/javascript are their respective defaults.

HTML5 spec links

  • Using link
  • Using style
  • Using script
<!-- External CSS -->
<link rel="stylesheet" href="code-guide.css">

<!-- In-document CSS -->
<style>
  /* ... */
</style>

<!-- External JavaScript -->
<script src="code-guide.js"></script>

<!-- In-document JavaScript -->
<script>
  /* ... */
</script>

Practicality over purity

Strive to maintain HTML standards and semantics, but not at the expense of practicality. Use the least amount of markup with the fewest intricacies whenever possible.

Attribute order

HTML attributes should come in this particular order for easier reading of code.

  • class
  • id, name
  • data-*
  • src, for, type, href, value
  • title, alt
  • aria-*, role

Classes make for great reusable components, so they come first. Ids are more specific and should be used sparingly (e.g., for in-page bookmarks), so they come second.

<a class="..." id="..." data-modal="toggle" href="#">
  Example link
</a>

<input class="form-control" type="text">

<img src="..." alt="...">

Boolean attributes

A boolean attribute is one that needs no declared value. XHTML required you to declare a value, but HTML5 has no such requirement.

For further reading, consult the WhatWG section on boolean attributes:

The presence of a boolean attribute on an element represents the true value, and the absence of the attribute represents the false value.

If you must include the attribute's value, and you don't need to, follow this WhatWG guideline:

If the attribute is present, its value must either be the empty string or [...] the attribute's canonical name, with no leading or trailing whitespace.

In short, don't add a value.

<input type="text" disabled>

<input type="checkbox" value="1" checked>

<select>
  <option value="1" selected>1</option>
</select>

Reducing markup

Whenever possible, avoid superfluous parent elements when writing HTML. Many times this requires iteration and refactoring, but produces less HTML. Take the following example:

<!-- Not so great -->
<span class="avatar">
  <img src="...">
</span>

<!-- Better -->
<img class="avatar" src="...">

JavaScript generated markup

Writing markup in a JavaScript file makes the content harder to find, harder to edit, and less performant. Avoid it whenever possible.

Discussion point/investigation: do we need a JS templating engine of some kind?

CSS

Syntax

  • Use soft tabs with two spaces—they're the only way to guarantee code renders the same in any environment.
  • When grouping selectors, keep individual selectors to a single line.
  • Include one space before the opening brace { of declaration blocks for legibility.
  • Place closing braces } of declaration blocks on a new line.
  • Include one space after : for each declaration.
  • Each declaration should appear on its own line for more accurate error reporting.
  • End all declarations with a semi-colon. The last declaration's is optional, but your code is more error prone without it.
  • Comma-separated property values should include a space after each comma (e.g., box-shadow).
  • Don't include spaces after commas within rgb(), rgba(), hsl(), hsla(), or rect() values. This helps differentiate multiple color values (comma, no space) from multiple property values (comma with space).
  • Don't prefix property values or color parameters with a leading zero (e.g., .5 instead of 0.5 and -.5px instead of -0.5px).
  • Lowercase all hex values, e.g., #fff. Lowercase letters are much easier to discern when scanning a document as they tend to have more unique shapes.
  • Use shorthand hex values where available, e.g., #fff instead of #ffffff.
  • Quote attribute values in selectors, e.g., input[type="text"]. They’re only optional in some cases, and it’s a good practice for consistency.
  • Use single quotes for multi-word fonts and background-image references
  • Avoid specifying units for zero values, e.g., margin: 0; instead of margin: 0px;.

Questions on the terms used here? See the syntax section of the Cascading Style Sheets article on Wikipedia.

/* terminology reminder */
[selector] {
    [property]: [value];
    [<--declaration--->]
}

/* Bad CSS */
.selector, .selector-secondary, .selector[type=text]{
  box-shadow:0px 1px 2px #CCC,inset 0 1px 0 #FFFFFF;
  font-family: Times New Roman,Helevtica,verdana;
  padding:15px;
  background-color:rgba(0, 0, 0,0.5);
  margin:0px 0px 0px 15px}

/* Good CSS */
.selector,
.selector-secondary,
.selector[type="text"] {
  padding: 15px;
  margin-left: 15px;
  font-family: 'Times New Roman', Helevtica, Verdana;
  background-color: rgba(0,0,0, .5);
  box-shadow: 0 1px 2px #ccc, inset 0 1px 0 #fff;
}

Declaration order

Related property declarations should be grouped together following the order:

  1. Positioning
  2. Box model
  3. Typographic
  4. Visual

Positioning comes first because it can remove an element from the normal flow of the document and override box model related styles. The box model comes next as it dictates a component's dimensions and placement.

Everything else takes place inside the component or without impacting the previous two sections, and thus they come last.

TODO: when we discuss tooling, perhaps Recess becomes a part of our CSS linting strategy?

.declaration-order {
  /* Positioning */
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  right: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  left: 0;
  z-index: 100;

  /* Box-model */
  display: block;
  float: right;
  width: 100px;
  height: 100px;

  /* Typography */
  font: normal 13px "Helvetica Neue", sans-serif;
  line-height: 1.5;
  color: #333;
  text-align: center;

  /* Visual */
  background-color: #f5f5f5;
  border: 1px solid #e5e5e5;
  border-radius: 3px;

  /* Misc */
  opacity: 1;
}

Don't use @import

Compared to <link>s, @import is slower, adds extra page requests, and can cause other unforeseen problems. Avoid them and instead opt for an alternate approach:

  • Use multiple <link> elements
  • Compile your CSS with the Sass preprocessor into a single file
  • Concatenate your CSS files with features provided in Rails, Jekyll, and other environments

For more information, read this article by Steve Souders.

<!-- Use link elements -->
<link rel="stylesheet" href="core.css">

<!-- Avoid @imports -->
<style>
  @import url("more.css");
</style>

Media query placement

Place media queries as close to their relevant rule sets whenever possible. Don't bundle them all in a separate stylesheet or at the end of the document. Doing so only makes it easier for folks to miss them in the future. Here's a typical setup.

.element { ... }
.element-avatar { ... }
.element-selected { ... }

@media (min-width: 480px) {
  .element { ...}
  .element-avatar { ... }
  .element-selected { ... }
}

Prefixed properties

When using vendor prefixed properties, indent each property such that the declaration's value lines up vertically for easy multi-line editing.

TODO: when discussing tooling, should autoprefixer become part of our workflow?

/* Prefixed properties */
.selector {
  -webkit-box-shadow: 0 1px 2px rgba(0,0,0,.15);
          box-shadow: 0 1px 2px rgba(0,0,0,.15);
}

Single declarations

In instances where a rule set includes only one declaration, consider removing line breaks for readability and faster editing. Any rule set with multiple declarations should be split to separate lines.

The key factor here is error detection—e.g., a CSS validator stating you have a syntax error on Line 183. With a single declaration, there's no missing it. With multiple declarations, separate lines is a must for your sanity.

/* Single declarations on one line */
.span1 { width: 60px; }
.span2 { width: 140px; }
.span3 { width: 220px; }

/* Multiple declarations, one per line */
.sprite {
  display: inline-block;
  width: 16px;
  height: 15px;
  background-image: url(../img/sprite.png);
}
.icon           { background-position: 0 0; }
.icon-home      { background-position: 0 -20px; }
.icon-account   { background-position: 0 -40px; }

Shorthand notation

Strive to limit use of shorthand declarations to instances where you must explicitly set all the available values. Common overused shorthand properties include:

  • padding
  • margin
  • font
  • background
  • border
  • border-radius

Often times we don't need to set all the values a shorthand property represents. For example, HTML headings only set top and bottom margin, so when necessary, only override those two values. Excessive use of shorthand properties often leads to sloppier code with unnecessary overrides and unintended side effects.

The Mozilla Developer Network has a great article on shorthand properties for those unfamiliar with notation and behavior.

/* Bad example */
.element {
  margin: 0 0 10px;
  background: red;
  background: url("image.jpg");
  border-radius: 3px 3px 0 0;
}

/* Good example */
.element {
  margin-bottom: 10px;
  background-color: red;
  background-image: url("image.jpg");
  border-top-left-radius: 3px;
  border-top-right-radius: 3px;
}

Nesting in Sass

Avoid unnecessary nesting. Just because you can nest doesn't mean you should. Consider nesting only if you must scope styles to a parent and if there are multiple elements to be nested. Overuse of nesting can easily lead to "selector-itis" and a long depth of applicability.

// Without nesting
.table > thead > tr > th { … }
.table > thead > tr > td { … }

// With nesting
.table > thead > tr {
  > th { … }
  > td { … }
}

Comments

Code is written and maintained by people. Ensure your code is descriptive, well commented, and approachable by others. Great code comments convey context or purpose. Do not simply reiterate a component or class name.

Be sure to write in complete sentences for larger comments and succinct phrases for general notes.

In sass files use // Single line comments providing your comment is one line.

/* Bad example */
/* Modal header */
.modal-header {
  ...
}

/* Good example */
/* Wrapping element for .modal-title and .modal-close */
.modal-header {
  ...
}

Selectors and specificity

When writing CSS, you should have a firm understanding of specificity and its implications.

  • do not rely on HTML structure and avoid rules bound to HTML elements
  • do not qualify selectors with HTML tag names
  • use classes over generic element tag for optimum rendering performance
  • avoid using several attribute selectors (e.g., [class^="..."]) on commonly occuring components. Browser performance is known to be impacted by these
  • avoid #ids to the greatest extent possible; avoid override predicaments and too much specificity
  • if you must use an id selector make sure that you have no more than one in your rule declaration. A rule like #header .search #quicksearch { ... } is considered harmful
  • using !important is like waiving a big red flag: step away and evaluate what the real problem is
  • use child selectors to limit the scope of selectors to direct descendants instead of all descendants. Note: child selectors make for relatively poor performance so use with caution!
  • use js-* classes to denote behavior (as opposed to style), but keep these classes out of your CSS
  • never reference js-* prefixed class names from CSS files

Good reads on specificty:

  • css-tricks.com/specifics-on-css-specificity
  • csswizardry.com/2012/07/shoot-to-kill-css-selector-intent

Limiting the Depth of Applicability

According to Jonathan Snook:

The depth of applicability is the number of generations that are affected by a given rule. smacss.com/book/applicability

A high depth of applicability means that components cannot be easily moved around; CSS is reliant on the HTML structure of the page. Multiple CSS rules end up competing in styling a particular element on the page (!important) and our CSS becomes less maintable and reusable. Ideally we want to reduce the depth of applicability in order to decouple our html and css and so create more modular sites.

/* Examples of bad CSS */

/* uses id; qualified with HTML tag name */
h2#headline {
  font-size: 36px;
}

/* CSS and HTML are tightly coupled */
#sidebar div {
    border: 1px solid #333;
}

#sidebar div h3 {
  margin-top: 5px;
}

#sidebar div ul {
  margin-bottom: 5px
}

/* uses id; more than one id in rule; qualified with HTML tag name */
div#page #sidebar h2.title {
  color: green;
}

/* js-* hook in CSS */
.js-visible: {
  display: block;
}

/* uses generic element for styling */
span {
  color: red;
}

/* depth of applicability of 5
   CSS is tied directly to the HTML structure of the page :(
*/
body.article #page #sidebar p span {
  color: red;
}

/* depth of applicability of 1
   CSS knows nothing about the HTML; we can move the class
   to any element on the page and the style will apply :)
*/
.some-thing {
  color: red;
}

Class names

  • Keep classes lowercase and use dashes (not underscores or camelCase). Dashes serve as natural breaks in related class (e.g., .btn and .btn-danger).
  • Avoid excessive and arbitrary shorthand notation. .btn is useful for button, but .s doesn't mean anything.
  • Use meaningful names; use structural or purposeful names over presentational.

It's also useful to apply many of these same rules when creating Sass and Less variable names.

/* Bad example */
.t { ... }
.red { ... }
.header { ... }

/* Good example */
.tweet { ... }
.warning-error { ... }
.warning-critical { ... }
.tweet-header { ... }

Organization

  • Organize sections of code by component.
  • Develop a consistent commenting hierarchy.
  • Use consistent white space to your advantage when separating sections of code for scanning larger documents.
  • When using multiple CSS files, break them down by component instead of page. Pages can be rearranged and components moved.
/*
 * Component section heading
 */

.element { ... }


/*
 * Component section heading
 *
 * Sometimes you need to include optional context for the entire component. Do that up here if it's important enough.
 */

.element { ... }

/* Contextual sub-component or modifer */
.element-heading { ... }

Editor configuration

Set your editor to the following settings to avoid common code inconsistencies and dirty diffs:

  • Use soft-tabs set to two spaces: not 4 spaces and not tabs. Spaces are the only way to guarantee code renders the same in any person's environment
  • Trim trailing white space on save.
  • Set encoding to UTF-8.
  • Add new line at end of files.

The .editorconfig file:

  • lives in the project root but can be in any directory (root = false)
  • helps developers define and maintain consistent coding styles
  • support for various IDE's an editors: IntelliJ & WebStorm, Sublime Text

An example .editorconfig file

root = true

# Unix-style newlines with a newline ending every file

[*]
end_of_line = lf
insert_final_newline = true
charset = utf-8
trim_trailing_whitespace = true

# 2 space indentation for these file types

[*.js, *.jsp, *.scss, *.css]
indent_style = space
indent_size = 2

[*.md]
trim_trailing_whitespace = false
